transcript.content: Back to form there - Oasis and Little By Little. This is Xfm 104.9, I'm Ricky Gervais, who are you?
Er, my name's Steve Merchant, good to see you.
Thanks. Er, with us, er, the producer in the studio is Karl Pilkington. And he'll be doing the m-buttons...
Yeah? You made a good effort there...
Ricky laughs
But er, once again...
Got bored.
Words are your enemy Rick, and they defeated you once again.
Ricky laughs
Just ran out of steam with the sentences.
Ohh, every week I think right, I'm really gonna make an effort now.
Yeah.
I'm gonna, I've, I've chosen some records...
Yeah.
That's it.
That's it. That's as far as it goes isn't it?
Yeah.
Maybe you should write out what you're gonna say at the top of the show?
Ricky laughs
Write that out. Get a nice big crayon.
No, I like to keep a little bit of...
Ricky clicks his fingers
You know.
Little bit of sumin'. Little bit of spark. Little bit of liveliness to it, sure.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Sure, sure, sure, sure.
Yeah.
How are you? Good, good to see you
Yeah, great. It's great to be er...
It's great to be out
Ricky laughs
Out of the house again.

Yeah. Oh, yeah. Just, erm, I was going to say because we've been doing this for a long time now with a little break, erm, but XFM are bringing new listeners all the time. I've heard four or five a week.
Really?
Yeah.
Wow, man alive.
New listeners tune in to XFM 104.9.
Radio 1 beware!
Ricky laughs
Yeah, yeah. And, uh, we might take it for granted that people that know who we are, know who you are, know who Karl is.
Sure.
Um.
Old listeners, certainly.
Now, if, if, if you, you know, if you're a regular then you know exactly who we are. But, erm, for those of you who don't, uh, I'll say I'm, I'm Ricky Gervais.
Ricky Gervais, BAFTA-award winning actor and, uh--
Yeah, yeah.
And writer.
Steve Merchant, erm, all those.
Friend of yours.
Yeah, yeah. And, this is the important thing, Karl Pilkington.
Absolutely.

Our, erm, produ-- I say producer. He was the bloke who was lumbered with the job. When I said, "Listen--" See I used to run the desk in the old days when I was working for XFM, I used to press the buttons and run the desk and everything. And then I said, "Listen, I've been on the telly, I do not press my own buttons." And Karl said, "Well, I don't really work weekends." And they went, "Well, you do if you want to keep your job."
Absolutely.
And we were lumbered with him. And then we discovered that he's not just a, a little, like a little dork. A little Manc-y, sort of, idiot.
Sure. Sure.
He's got, he's got a nice shirt. He's got, you know what I mean? He's got something else.
Absolutely. He brings another dimension, yeah.
Yeah. And, uh, he, he started having a little chat and we discovered--
We both love him.
That he had quite a lot to say.

Mm. Well I, I think you're absolutely right and I think, um- I was wondering maybe we should maybe play another tune. But after that, I just think we should refamiliarize our radio audience with Karl.
Yeah.
And any new listeners, just get- let, somehow, kind of let them get to know the real Karl again.
Well if you are new, you'll, you'll find that we like some old songs, some new songs, some chitter-chat. Uh, we get serious sometimes.
Oh yeah.
There's some tears and some laughter.
Yeah.
We kicked off with Oasis's new one, "Little by Little". We're going to go back in time now to Iggy Pop and his Stooges with "I'm Bored."
Iggy Pop - I'm Bored
Iggy Pop, "I'm Bored" on XFM 104.9. I'm Ricky Gervais.
Steve Merchant here.
Yeah. Little Karl Pilkington. Well, to reintroduce or introduce people to the first time to Karl, um, I think we should have a--
Yeah, maybe sort of a, kind of, a quick Q&A Karl, and we don't need, sort of, lengthy answers from you. We don't need lots of detail. Uh, you know, it can be a, just a couple of sentences--
Just to get a flavor of who you are.
To answer these questions. Yeah, so firstly, name obviously Karl Pilkington. Age, Karl?
I'll be, uh, I'll be thirty next month.
Really?
This month. No next, wha- where are we?
Ricky and Steve burst into laughter
I don't think we need to ask any more questions.
I, I don't- I think we've done it.
That's it.
I think we've done it there.
Welcome to the world of Karl Pilkington.
Ricky chuckles
I think- Oh, I thought it would take three or four questions--
I thought it was going to at least--
To really explain what Karl is about.
Yeah, that was, that was the first question.
Ricky and Steve laugh
Oh, oh God!
Absolutely incredible. But um, but we can't really leave it there cause, um--
No.
Because we haven't got enough else to do to fill up the two hours.
No.
So, um, so let's pursue this line of inquiry.
Yeah.
So, um, age? What was the age, Karl? In a couple of--
When were you, when were you born?
I'll be, uh-- '72.
Right, what month, what day?
I'm on the cusp.
Ricky and Steve snigger
You're on the cusp of a day?
Um, twenty-third of September.
Ok.
So anyway-- ok, alright. Good.
And there you were talking there about, um, obviously your star sign, were you, on the cusp?
Yep.
You believe in that, do you?
No.
You don't believe in star signs?
No, not really.
But you do believe in ghosts, I understand.
No, because the star signs--
The paranormal.
Yeah, but the star sign thing, you've got how many, how many different star signs are they?
Twelve, innit?
Right, and then you've got, like, loads of people.
Yeah. You do the math.
So they're saying that, you know, there's only twelve different sorts of people in the world.
Exactly. That's exactly right. It's, it's made-up. It's made-up nonsense. It's non-science.
It's pseudo-science.
It's, yes. It's, it's, it's, it's hairy-man and, um, dyed-hair-woman science.
Yes.
Innit?
Alright?
Yeah.
Anyway, back to you, Karl. Where were you born?
In, uh, in Manchester.
Okay. What GCSE results did you get?
Ricky sniggers
I got, uh, was it an E? Got an E in history.
You got an E in history. And how did you find out that?
You found out.
Cause you thought you, you didn't, you couldn't remember what you got. You didn't turn up and you thought you'd done about three, one of which wasn't history, and actually--
I knew, I knew I did art.
Yeah, you didn't. I'm telling you didn't cause we checked. You did one. You turned up for history, you did history, you got an E in history.
No, I definitely did art. I made a little clay man.
Steve laughs
Yeah, you've got to register for O-levels. You don't just do it and then phone 'em up and say, "How was that?" And they go--
"I'm sending you a clay man."
Ricky laughs
"Send me a grade."
Yeah, yeah. There's all things, there's forms to fill out and things like that, Karl.
Anyway...
Yeah, go on.
Ricky sniggers
Who was your closet childhood friend?
Closest. At what age?
Well, when you were young, when you were--
Oh, I remember this. It's a fella. Um, someone Makin, innit?
There's, there's, well he wasn't really a close mate. Darren Buckley was me--
Darren Buckley?
Yeah.
Tell us briefly about Darren. I'd forgotten about Darren.
He's the one who, um, all the, all the girls liked him.
Did they?
He had, uh, he had permed hair. Used to--
Ricky quietly laughs
Have his hair like a footballer.
Sure.
Um--
Were you jealous of him?
His dad was a copper.
Did you hang around with Darren, like, in the hope of getting of, maybe, his, kind of, castoffs?
Nah. I, I- You see, it's weird with me. I wasn't that bothered about having loads of mates an' that. I sort of--
Sure.
I had lots of mates, but I could do without 'em.
You had a magpie, didn't you?
I was happy, I was happy playing with me magpie.
Yeah, and what happened to him?
It, uh, flew away.
Yeah.
But I wasn't bothered because it was giving me grief towards the end, wasn't it. It was--
Ricky laughs
It was popping me, me Grifter tyres an' that.
Ricky continues to laugh
Yeah, sure.
Flying down, pecking me head.
Sure. Now you went to school with a number or different interesting people. Some of whom are freaks.
Two of which, I understand, had big heads and webbed toes.
Is that right?
Yet they were not related to each other and they weren't friends with each other. Why weren't they friends with each other?
Because that'd be obvious.
Ricky laughs
Did they, did they wear shoes or did they walk around in their, in their webbed, uh, feet?
Were they good at swimming? Were they good at swimming?
Uh, I don't know. I don't they ever, ever went swimming.
Did they ever talk, did they, did they ever look over at each other and think--
"Yeah, we should hang out more."
Ricky laughs
I told you something in the week, as well, there was another lad at school- had a pigeon chest.
He had a what?
Can we come back to this?
He had a pigeon chest?
I think we should play a record, Karl. Cause we, I think we've hooked them now. I think, I think--
Yeah. There's no one switching off now, Rick.
No, play a record.
Blur - Coffee & TV
Blur, "Coffee & TV." Karl, uh- I said, "It's not the best Blur song" when it was playing, you know, I don't want to diss it, but it's not the best one, I mean, that, that's fact, you know?
Absolutely, sure.
Karl went, "I like the video though. Had a little milk carton."
Yeah.

"Bit sad. It's tragic, innit?" He went, and this is all to himself. I'm not even joining in. And then he went, “Yeah, but it’s alright in the end.” He goes, “He finds a little girl milk carton.” Just lives out a little thing in his- is that like you on your paper round, that little milk carton walking around like that? I imagine you…oh, people that don’t know about, if you just tuned in Karl had a paper round--
It’s his favorite job ever.
And he maintains it’s the best job he’s ever had. Innit, Karl?
Karl starts to talk then sighs
Go on.
I don’t know what’s so weird about that.
It’s a paper round.
Yeah, but look- forget all that.
It’s not the most fulfilling of jobs.
Look at, look at the way it works, right. You get it out of the way at the start of the day so you got the rest of the day to yourself.
Ricky quietly laughs
Sure.
Just as the same as signing on.
Your own, you’re your own boss, you know?
Same as signing on.
Well you’re not your own boss. The guy at the news agency is your boss.
Ricky laughs
Yeah.
Nahhh…
Ricky and Steve laugh
That’s great.
You’ve proven me wrong there, yeah.
Yeah, that’s great. Nahhhhh. Yeah, nahhhhh, not really. Would that stand up in court? “Well you were found with the dagger.” “Nahhhhhhhhhh.”
Steve laughs
“Was I?”
When are we, uh, when are we playing me new game?
Oh, Karl’s got a new game. Karl’s so excited. Oh, just--
Well we were talking about something before--
Yeah, the freaks he used to go, the people with big heads, two webbed feet, didn’t hang around each other, that would be too obvious. Um, you had a fella with a pigeon chest.
Yeah, what’s the story with the pigeon chest?
Don’t know how it happened. It was like, it looked like somebody sort of hit him on the back with a big hammer and it had come out of the front.
Yeah.
And I’ve never seen it since.
Could that have been the answer?
What, why his, why he had it?
Yeah, why he had it. Possibly, I suppose, in your neck of the woods.
Yeah. I dunno, I never asked him.
It’s just come back to haunt you, has it, the pigeon chest?

No, it’s just that, uh, you know, when you, when you mentioned about kids at school I forgot all about him. You’re talking about the kids with the webbed feet and the big heads and I forgot about the little, old--
Pigeon chest.
Pigeon boy.
Well listen are you- I’m a big fan of that TV show, it’s on digital TV, a lot of people won’t have it, but “Inside the Actor’s Studio” with James Lipton.
Yeah, yeah.
And he interviews lots of big Hollywood stars and he always asks them these same questions at the end. Can I just run a few of ‘em past you?
Go on.
Okay. So, um, if you could do any other profession other than the one you do now, what profession would you do?
Can you just change that to “apart from a paper round”?
Apart from a paper round?
Ooh…
You could do any other profession, Karl.
Erm, and it doesn’t matter about, like--
It doesn’t matter if you’ve got the skills or anything, in an ideal world, if you had the ability.
Well, I think I’m about to buy somewhere so I reckon something, you know, using, using tools and like doing a bit of plumbing an’ that.
So a plumber.
Well, sort of an all-rounder.
Right, right.
A handy man.
Well, yeah, yeah. I think, you know, you don’t get paid that much, but it’s useful, innit. So--
You could get your own show, couldn’t you, with Carol Smillie eventually?
Well, all that, but the money that you don’t make, you save by not having to pay someone else do the chores, do you know what I mean?
Right, okay. I, I don’t know what that sentence meant.
Steve hoots
Right, right, look. A plumber, how much, how much is the average plumber on?
The money you don’t make, you save on not getting someone else to do it. No, just think of that, no break that sentence down. Is there any--
Sorry, Rick, sorry, but, uh… people who live in glass houses.
Ricky laughs
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Anyway, let’s go back to Lipton quickly. We’ve got a couple to get through here. So your favorite noise or sound?
Uh…
Favorite sound or noise?
Ooh…
Is it me?
No.
It’s not me?
Er, hang on a minute.
Ricky gets louder
It’s not me? Are you sure it’s not me, Karl?
I like, I like Elvis.
Noise. Who? Elvis?
Elvis. “In the Ghetto.”
The sound of Elvis.
Elvis, “In the Ghetto.” Brilliant.
Okay, and your least favorite noise or sound? I don’t think it should really be records and music. Noises, things that you hear. At home or whatever.
Uhh… Maybe like the sound of a--
Least favorite noise.
Least favorite…
Sound of--
Probably, like, uh--
Sound of ghosts?
Fire engines an’ that.
Right.
That’s, that’s annoying.
Ricky laughs
Except if your house was on fire, presumably.
I think it’s a bit unnecessary.
Ricky and Steve laugh
You think that they’re just doing it to wind people up?
I live on, like, a busy street and it’s happening all the time and it‘s, it is like… just sort of have a blast of it and people will hear it.
Sure.
You don’t have to keep it going.
Sure, sure.
So that is, yeah, pretty annoying.
Okay, and, um, if Heaven exists, Karl, when you get to the Pearly gates, what would you like God to say to you as he welcomes you into Heaven? What would you like God to say to you?
Uhh…who asks these? Wha-what shows this?
It’s a program where, um, celebrities are interviewed by a guy, an American interviewer, and he always asks these questions at the very end.
What would I say to God?
What would you say to God- If you believed in Heaven and if Heaven exists, when you eventually got to Heaven and you’re welcomed in through the gates--
Like Parker, in your stussy t-shirt and your--
Yeah, what do you want God to say to you as he welcomes you in?
Say, uh, “You alright?” Uh, dunno just be, just be friendly.
Ricky and Steve laugh
The Reindeer Section- Grand Parade
That’s The Reindeer Section.
Beautiful.
Yeah, nice stuff. Um, it’s a kind of Scottish super-group, lots of different artists--
Belle and Sebastian.
Ricky and Steve talk over each other
Is it the lead singer from ‘em?

It may well be, yeah, on that particular track. Different people, Mull Historical Society, Idlewild, Teenage Fanclub, different people from all those bands get together with a guy called Gary Lightbody from Snow Patrol and he writes the tunes.
And all that on XFM 104.9, Steve.
Ab-solutely. Let me just name that track, that track was “Grand Parade” from their current album, “Son of Evil Reindeer.”
Feeder, “Come Back Around” on XFM 104.9. I’m Ricky Gervais. Uhh.. but who are you?
Oh, thanks for asking, Rick. Steve Merchant.
With us, Karl Pilkington. Well, Karl, um- Now, I know I shouldn’t, but I met Karl in the week again, Steve.
I tell you you shouldn’t do this, you know you shouldn’t--

I know, but then when he starts, he starts saying things like, “I was a (unintelligible)”, I go, “No, no. Save it, save it.” And then we just sit there and I’m scared to talk in case he comes up- But, um, you did tell me a couple of little things, didn’t ya? True stories, that are, I mean I enjoyed it. Can you tell, um, Steve the one about the doctor?
Right--
Oh God. Is this something that happened to a friend of yours, or is this a--
No, no. I read about it.
You read about it, okay.
Um…there’s this little lad, right? First of all, it’s years ago, right?
What, in olden times?
They didn’t have, they didn’t have decent doctors in, like, every town an’ that.
Yeah.
And, uh, this little kid, he’s dead ill, right.
Yeah.
And the local doctor--
Well, there’s a phone call involved so I don’t want people to get the impression that it‘s--
Well let me get to it!
Medieval times.

Err… yeah, but I didn’t say that, I just said it’s years ago. So this kid’s ill, right, and he’s lying in the bed and he’s all, like, all going funny color an’ that. And his mom says, “I’m gonna get the local doctor ‘round.” The local doctor comes ‘round and says, “Ooh.. Dunno, dunno what’s up with him.” He said, um, leave it with me--
Ricky and Steve laugh.
Leave it with me.
Leave it with me. What, the doctor said that?
Yeah, he said, “I’ll, um, I’ll phone up a top doctor--”
Okay.

Who was in America, or somethin’ like that. And, uh, so he goes to the phone in his office and he calls America and cause it’s years ago, the phone line isn’t that good, it’s all crackly an’ that, alright. So he’s talking to the doctor and he’s saying, “I’ve got this kid, he’s a funny color and, uh… you know, he’s really weak an’ that.”
He’s not giving him much to go on.
So, uh, so the American doctor, right? He goes, “Yeah, what you want to do-” and it’s all breaking up, right? He goes, “What you’ve got to do, you’ve got to--”
Karl mimics a phone call breaking up
It’s all breaking up. “You’ve got to give him some, uh… parrot’s blood.” Right?
Some parrots blood?
Well, that’s what he thought he said. But the line was really bad, he meant parent’s blood, but he heard that he said “parrot’s blood.”
Oh God.
He said, “Okay, I’ll do that. Leave it to me.”
I can see where this is going.
He goes, goes to, uh, a pet shop. Said, “Give us, like, half a dozen parrots.”
Sure.
Takes ‘em around to the kid’s house. Takes the blood from the parrots, puts it in the kid, kid’s fine.
The kid’s fine?
It worked.
Ricky laughs
I’ve never heard such a load of shite in my life.
Steve laughs
I never heard such twaddle, such, just made up enhanced, exaggerated…bollocks in my life.
What a load of old rubbish, Karl.
I mean, when he told me this, he said the doctor said, “Well what do I do?” And the doctor on the other end said, “Give him some blood.” And the doctor went, “Where do I get blood from?”
Ricky and Steve laugh
So, hang on--
“Where do I get blood from?” “Get him some parent’s blood.” Give him some parent’s blood! Give  him some parent’s, some parent’s blood! Yeah…
Ricky and Steve laugh
But hang on, I just need to know where you read this--
Sorry, Karl, I’ve stitched you up. You know when he said, he said, “So do you believe that?” I went, “Tell it to Steve.” He went, “Do you believe it?” I went, “Tell it to Steve!” Karl…
That, that was on the internet. About illnesses.
Where is it on the internet? What, what webpage?
I was looking at stuff, I was looking at stuff this morning cause of, um, Uri Geller last night.
Ricky laughs
Eating all that funny food an’ that and also, uh- They all got a bit scared last night, didn’t they, with the snake.
I didn’t see it last night. Is this “I’m a Celebrity…Get Me Out of Here!”?
Yeah, yeah. Got all worried about a snake getting on the, uh, sort of wanderin’ about in between the sleeping bags an’ stuff. And, um, they were all scared and--
Leave it with me! Sorry, the doctor says, “Leave it with me.”
Leave it with me.
Ricky laughs
Yeah, ahh….leave it with me.
Well, they were all scared cause there’s a snake and it’s so easy to find stuff out. Before they, before they- where are they? Where is this jungle?
Australia, I think.
Fully went, give it half an hour on the internet, I found out with snakes you don’t need to worry, right? Um, they’re deaf, they don’t got any ears, so as long as you’re really quiet--
Creep around.
They’ll probably leave you alone. And also they don’t have eyelids.
Uh-huh.
Erm, so they were suggesting, if one’s coming towards you, just, like, kick sand in its eyes.
Ricky quietly laughs
Cause it can’t blink and it leaves it a bit, like, annoyed.
Yeah.
And it wanders off. But they didn’t do any research before they went.
Yeah.

That- your, your- I think your knowledge was probably in good stead. I don’t think you need to know any more than you know. Um, well we’re going to come back to that because he also explained to me where, uh, a saying comes from that I want you to be part of. But, uh--
Oh, and also we should mention as well, Karl you’ve come up with a competition, is this right?
Brilliant competition.
He thinks this can go to television.
Is this an idea you’ve come up with?
Yeah.
Karl, I’m so looking forward to it.

So am, I mean, I’m looking forward to it. Um, continuing, uh, our exposure of myths and legends, apocryphal tale, we exposed that myth that some maybe older rockers have had it and they’ve got, they were never any good and the kids today--
Oh, I don’t want to hear that.
People like Rod Stewart--
Rod Stewart is a great artist. He’s a slightly laughable man, but a great artist.
Let’s got back to when it was, when he was rocking.
When he cut the mustard?
Yeah!
Rod Stewart- You Wear It Well
Rod Stewart, “You Wear It Well.”
Great tune.

On XFM 104.9. Yeah, this doctor, I mean, we should find out who he is, really, and if he’s still practicing cause it, it worries me a little bit. That he, you know, did that. Also, I mean, he thinks he got away with it, but how could he be sure those parrots wouldn’t talk?
True, true.
Do you know what I mean? There were six of them. They probably got together, and, they prob- they probably put it on the internet.
I mean, I feel that that story, Karl, it asks more questions than it answers, really.
Ricky laughs
Yeah, like most of your stories, to be honest.
Yeah, that’s the problem. I always feel them- I always feel like I need a little more information, like did the parrot boy continue to live?
Yeah.
You know, to a ripe old age or did he die weeks later after this charlatan doctor who was going around, you know--
Did he break his nose trying to crack a big nut?
No, I think, I think he’s, uh, he was alright. He, he lived to a--
See, I’d have shou- If I was that doctor, I would have shouted that down the phone, “Are you sure you said ‘parrot’s blood’?”
Yeah.
“Are you sure it was parrot’s blood?”
“Listen, I-I mean, you know, I’m not the best doctor in the world, but did you say ‘parrot’s blood’?”
Steve chuckles
Yeah, but what you’re forgetting is you’re going back to the time where, like, they used leeches to do, like--
No, no we’re not!
We’re going back to the late ‘70s, if there’s a phone call to America direct.
C’mon Karl, they weren’t calling America, like, in the medieval times or-or in the Victorian age. Karl, think about it, Karl.
(quietly): Yeah.
You know, this has got to be, like, the, like, you know,‘30s or ‘40s at the earliest. You know?
Ricky giggles
Alright.
I’m intrigued to know where this- I think there’s someone on web who’s just putting information on there to lead you astray.
Yeah.
Cause you’re the only person who finds this stuff. Other people are using this to write theses…
Why were you, why were you looking at that then? What were you…
I always look at weird stuff.
What were you looking for?
But what do you type in the search engine to find ‘parrot blood’ stories?
What were you looking for? Wha--
There was this woman with a weird head.
Ricky laughs
Why were you looking for that? What were you--
Just cause I’d heard about it, I’d heard, like, someone talking about it on another station, right.
Right.
About this woman with a, with a funny head.

Right, I love the fact, I love the fact you’re intrigued with these things. You go into the basement of Waterstones or Dillions or somewhere and there’s these, there’s these medical books that you’ll love ‘em, mate.
Yeah, but this is free on the internet, innit? It’s all there.
Yeah.
So what did you- you typed in ‘weird head woman’ or…
Ricky sings "Lady with head..."
Weir-weird, weird people, or something I put in.
Sure.
Yeah, did you come up?
Ricky and Steve laugh
Seven thousand hits, Karl Pilkington.
Ricky laughs
But it’s all there, innit. It’s interesting, the one that I was telling you before about, um, the what’s-her-name, the lost letter.
The lost letter. What’s this?

The lost, the lost postcard that’s, uh, just turned up. Some woman sent a postcard years and years ago to her niece or something and her niece was, like, three years old back then. And just now, like, I think, like, yesterday or the day before it turned up, the postcard turned up seventy-four years late.
Seventy-four years late?
It took seventy-four years.
And that three year old girl has been living in the same house that whole time.
Well, yeah.
Ricky laughs
There’s nowt weird about that.
You see what we mean when there’s always a question you can ask to just scratch the credibility of these stories. There’s always- it’s like the apocryphal tale--
Was this the slugs? Was this those slugs from last week? That were stealing--

Yeah. Cause the postman slug is useless. It’s round takes him seventy four years. And then he’s got to go back to the beginning and he’s got seventy four ye- and he can’t carry the bag. That’s when they go, that’s when they turn to glue, that’s why they turn to glue.
Ohh… It’s pitiful.
It is pitiful.
So you don’t believe that someone sent a postcard years ago and somehow it’s been stuck in the bottom of a postbag or something and it’s only just got--
Stuck in the bottom of a postbag? That means that there’s, like, a ninety-five year old postman who’s still wandering around!
Yeah, did, did she, did she have to pay, like, the, the difference on the charges?
Uh…
Cause presumably--
It wouldn’t have had Queen Elizabeth’s, uh--

Yeah, yeah.
And the other one is saying Karl--
XFM, Radio 1 with less people.
Yeah, yeah. Um, and so despite the fact that it was a stolen idea, I think we should do it again next week. Next week, let’s-let’s wrestle up some prizes as well.
You’re just like your little magpie, aren’t you? Thieving shiny ideas …from Mayo’s nest.
Absolutely. So, uh, anyway, we played Lynyrd Skynyrd just before the ads and I was looking at the compilation it comes from.
It’s a great compilation.
We took this from, uh, “Driving Rock.”
Yeah.
Uh, which I imagine is--
This is not available in the shops!
Exactly. Um, I imagine this comes straight from the personal collection of maybe Taryn or, uh, Foxy.
Or Camfield.
But there’s some great names on here that I’d like to see maybe we can play a little--
He’s a little Vance, isn’t he? He’s a tiny Vance. You know you’re like a little Mayo. Camfield’s a little Vance.
I mean, these are some names--
Go on.
I haven’t heard them for a long time--

Rea. You don’t hear Rea enough.

Yeah.
Mr. Big!
I didn’t--
He’s guilty, in that song when he goes--
I swear I did--
And all that and then the police came around, well there’s no smoke without fire. I reckon he did it.

Yeah.
Uhh-

Oh, there’s nothing wrong with them.

“Africa?”

When session musicians get together--

Oh, play a little bit of “Hold the Line!” That’s great.

That was dynamite.
That was great.

I, ohh--
Do you not think?
I’d love to. I’d love to. A bit of Rainbow, maybe, next week. Who knows?
Ohh, man alive.
Phone in if you want to hear some classic rock.
Classic rock, indeed.
Oh, we ripped off Mayo, let’s do Vance.

Okay.
Um--
Oh, wha-what could we have?
Oh, there’s some great ideas out there, I’m sure.
I-I mean, if you, if you wanted, like, any “Fix It” is done. If you, maybe, wanted to eat a pack lunch on a rollercoaster.

The Streets - Weak Becomes Heroes
The White Stripes-  Dead Leaves and the Dirty Ground
White Stripes, on XFM 104.9. I’m Ricky Gervais, with me Steve Merchant--
Hello.
Karl Pilkington. Well, I had a good time.
I’ve enjoyed it. Yeah, it’s been nice. Good fun.
Some good tracks, some, some laughs, some new, uh, competition by  Simon Mayo.
Steve laughs
Absolutely.
That was, that was great.
Yeah, yeah. Karl, have you heard, um, the big news? That, uh, Ricky Gervais is, uh, looking to take up, um- well, you explain it, Gervais, cause I’m not, I’m not--
No, it’s not big news.
No--
What are you talk- what do you mean?
You-you-you-you’re taking up boxing, in this right?
N-no.
What is the story? You want to be fighting for money?
No! Yeah, bare-knuckle fighting.
No, c’mon. What is it?
No, all it is, I’ve been watching this, um, show on cable called “Born to Fight” and it’s on sort of late--
Steve laughs
On later when you flick around and I think it’s on after “Roadies“, which is like--
“Roadies?”

Yeah, it’s a bloke, one bloke with a camera who goes on tour with different people. He went with Motorhead, he went with the Meatloaf, um, uh, uh, Tribute Act. He went on with Coldplay was in one of them. It’s this, sort of, cheap, sort of--
Is this when all the other channels have been switched off, this is the only one left?

Yeah, yeah. Yeah, exactly, yeah. And there’s one called “Born to Fight” and, uh, they just take a different story. It might be an amateur fight or it might be an unlicensed fight, not illegal. Um, or it might be white-collar, which is what I’m thinking of doing.
Wha-what’s white-collar?
White-collar is just people who want to fight and, uh, it’s organized--
Is it like “Fight Club?”

Yes, but it’s charity, it’s-it’s safe. It’s-it’s a charity do. You’ll have big events and it’s just two people that, you know, aren’t boxers, aren’t amateur boxers and they get in the ring and do three, three, um, two-minute rounds and they just lay into each other. They got headguards on and, uh--
Rick, I don’t mean to alarm you, but, um, you know, we work together, obviously, and we make “The Office” and stuff. Your face is my fortune.
Ricky laughs
Rick, I can’t have you--
It must be a bit of a worry for you.
It is. I’m not going- well, your heart is, as well, is also a concern.
Yeah.
And your eating and stuff.
Well, when I say--
No, no, no, wait a minute--
But when I said I was going to get fit, you were going, “No, Gervais. You’re only funny cause you’re fat.”
No, I agree, this is true. But I’m saying there’s a difference between being fit--
Yeah.
And, um, I would say for instance, don‘t eat--
Getting your face smashed in.
Well, don’t eat, don’t eat, kind of, you know, cheese and bacon, you know, on their own.
All day.

All day or for breakfast. So what I’m saying is there’s a difference between, you know, exercising and then having your face beaten in and what I’m saying is that you- I just don’t think it’s a good idea.
But I might win.
No, the prob- what I don’t- you- that’s-that’s-that’s irrelevant. You’re still going to take a couple blows to the face and the point is this, Rick, you’re not going to win.
Why?
No, because you are delusional. You think that you are probably the world’s greatest boxer.
Ricky laughs
Ever since I’ve known you, you’ve seemed to think that’s the case cause you’ve watched all the “Rocky” films--
Ricky continues to laugh
And you think, “That’s fair enough. That seems straightforward enough.” But look at your physique. Yeah, you’ve got some upper body strength--
Yeah.
But, you know, you’ve also got some up- some lower belly strength, as well, I’ve noticed.
Ricky laughs
And, um, and my concern is you’re going to go in there and you’re not only going to be a broken man when you realize that you’re just not as handy in the ring as you thought you were--
Yeah.
But also, you’re going to, you’re going to incur some injuries.
This is fighting talk. This is fighting talk.
The first rule of Fight Club is don’t talk about Fight Club.
This makes me want to do it more now, just cause of you. It was the same when Adrian didn’t agree that Rocky could beat--
Right.
Clubber Lang.
Yeah, yeah.
Oh, she-she made that mistake. Then she made the same mistake with Draco!
At what age, Rick, at what age--
Then she turns up at the end to take the credit, didn’t she?

When you were this, kind of, thin, nimble youth in your makeup and eyeliner and all the rest of it, you- I bet you had no id- you had no thoughts about boxing. It never came into your mind, did it? So at what age did you suddenly think, “Wait a minute, I’ve taken the wrong path in life. I could’ve been the world’s heavyweight.”
I don’t, I don’t think I could.
When have you, when have you suddenly decided that you can, you-you can suddenly be a bit street tough? I don’t understand why this has suddenly come about in later life.
Well, I’m not putting out a shout, am I, to fight people. It’s not- I’m not- it’s not like I’m Noel Gallegher and Robbie Williams.
But you’ve got to find somebody else to, presumably, fight with.
Yeah, but it’ll probably be a business man who wants to fight.
Right. You know there’s something really weird about that. Don’t you think that soun- have you just listened to yourself, “I want to fight another- I want to fight a businessman!”
Ricky laughs
“Please may I fight a businessman?”
No, I don’t want to fight a businessman!
You just said!
I want to fight someone who wants to- you know, it’s not--
“I want to fight them” now!
Ricky laughs
“I want to fight somebody.”
Say it like that, it sounds a bit mad, yeah.
“Bring ‘em on, I want to fight people.”

No, but it’s more- it’s more the effort and the training, the equipment to it, like climbing a mountain. I mean, I think climbing a mountain and doing a marathon is ridiculously macho. It’s not the fact that you can do it--
No, that’s not macho compared with boxing.

Well, it is macho, isn’t it? There’s no reason to climb a mountain, there’s no reason to do a marathon. If you can run a mile, that’s all you need. The fact that you train, is whether you can do it yourself and achieve something and this is more, like, the training and the learning a skill and seeing if it works. I-I don’t want to get in there--
But aren’t you concerned that you might get beaten? Or you might get beaten up, I should say.
No! What’s the worst that could happen?
You’ll get black eyes, bruises and--
Well, bruises, bruises heal.
Gervais, let me just remind you--
What?
Of the time we were working in your flat, right?
Ricky giggles
And you immediately- I think, I don’t know, to this day, what happened, but you started choking, you clasped your chest--
Ricky laughs
You were breathing, wheezing, right? I leapt over to you. I remember screaming, “I don’t know the Heimlich maneuver.”
Yeah.
“If you’ve swallowed something, I can’t help.”
Yeah.
You gained your breath, you gained your composure. I said, “What happened? Did you eat something, did it go down the wrong way?” You said, “No, I swallowed some dust.”
Ricky laughs
“I swallowed some dust.” You breathed some dust in that was in the air, there was some dust in the air, you breathed that in; it knocked you out for two days.
Ricky howls with laughter
Rick, you were in bed for two days.
Yeah. I love that.
I don’t think, I don’t think you’re the man for the job.
I had some dust. “What do you think this businessman’s going to do to you?” “Hurt ya permanent!”
Yeah!
“He’ll hurt ya permanent!”
You found a lump, didn’t you, on your testicle once. We sat in a doctor’s waiting room, I remember, for about forty-five minutes.
It all checked out, it was fine. I think I went twice, didn’t I? I said to the doctor at one point, I said, “Did you check ‘round the back?”
Yeah.
I was thinking he hadn’t checked it. Yeah. Oh, dear.
Yeah, just because he hadn’t found anything. My point is this--
Ohh…
You’re something of a hypochondriac.
Ricky laughs
You know you’re something of a hypochondriac. You know that already. So why do you think this is going to be any different?
Well--
If you take, when you take a  first blow to the head, you’ll take the punch, you’ll immediately think you’ve got some kind of, you know, brain disorder and--
No, I‘ve always--
And you’ll be done for. And you'll give up. You'll throw in the towel.
I’ve always wanted to do it, but I just thought- I just wanted to make sure, I wanted to know that I definitely lost my looks.
Right.
And, um, I’ve seen some of the publicity shots, I’ve got mirrors in my house, so now- I’ve definitely lost my looks now, I’ve got nothing to lose.
Yeah.
So I want, you know, maybe a younger, more handsome man. I want to teach him a lesson.
Rick, I’ll end with this.
What?
For people who listen to this show regularly, you already sound like you’re punch drunk.
Ricky laughs
Alright? And that’s just your natural way of talking. Please, let’s not do the real thing.
Oh, play a record. Ohh…
I mean, is it going to be televised?
Oh, it- well, we could get it on DVD, maybe we’ll release it.
Okay, now I’m interested.
Ricky laughs
Okay.
Is there money to be made?
Yeah, lots of money.
Alright, maybe we should talk about it.
Okay.
